data.title: 9 Bruno Guimaraes Facts From Childhood in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
data.meta_description: Discover 9 Bruno Guimarães facts from childhood in São Cristóvão, Rio de Janeiro, to European football stardom, unveiling family heritage and more.
data.text:
Full Name: Bruno Guimarães Rodriguez Moura

Date of Birth: 16 November 1997

Place of Birth: Rio de Janeiro, Brazil

Height: 1.82 m (6 ft 0 in)

Position(s): Central midfielder

Current Club: Newcastle United

Jersey Number: 39

Bruno Guimarães, the shining light from São Cristóvão, Rio de Janeiro, has emerged as a top talent in European football. Known for his commanding presence, physical prowess, and intense dedication, the Brazil-born midfielder, currently plying his trade in the Premier League, has become a household name in the football world.

Now, let's embark on a journey through 9 fascinating facts illuminating his childhood, highlighting his rich family heritage, pivotal moments in his career, and more.

Below Are 9 Bruno Guimaraes Facts From Childhood in Brazil to Premier League Stardom

1. He Has Spanish Heritage

Bruno Guimarães, also known as Bruxo ("The Wizard" in Portuguese), has a diverse cultural heritage. His family's roots trace back to Spain, where his grandfather immigrated to Brazil, settling in the municipality located in the state of Mato Grosso in the Central-West Region of Brazil, specifically in the city of Jarra.

Thanks to his grandfather, Bruno possesses Spanish citizenship alongside his Brazilian nationality. His complete name, Bruno Guimarães Rodriguez Moura, reflects his heritage, with "Guimarães" representing his maternal lineage and "Rodriguez Moura" his paternal lineage.

2. He Was Born in São Cristóvão, Rio de Janeiro

Bruno was born on November 16, 1997, in São Cristóvão, a neighbourhood in Rio de Janeiro known for its vibrant culture and robust footballing tradition, where the beautiful game serves as both a major passion and a pathway for many to overcome adversity and achieve success.

3. He Started His Football Career at Audax Rio before joining Athletico Paranaense

Bruno Guimarães began his youth career at Audax Rio, where his passion for the game blossomed. However, he officially joined Grêmio Osasco Audax in 2015, making his senior team debut in April at age 17 in a victory against Bragantino. His exceptional performances in the 2017 Copa São Paulo de Futebol Júnior earned him a promotion to the senior squad.

9 Top Football Managers Out Of Work.

In May 2017, he joined Athletico Paranaense on loan, initially featuring for the under-23 team. He debuted for the club in June 2017, securing his permanent signing in March 2018, and scoring his first senior goal a few days later as he contributed to a resounding victory over Rio Branco-PR.

His pivotal role under manager Tiago Nunes led to a contract renewal in February 2019. He was voted the best midfielder in the Brazilian championship and succeeded with Athletico Paranaense, winning the CONMEBOL Levain Cup and the Brazilian Cup.

4. Lyon Came Calling Following His Top Displays at Paranaense

On January 29, 2020, Brazil midfielder Bruno signed with Ligue 1 side Lyon for €20 million, with Athletico Paranaense securing a 20% sell-on clause. He signed a four-and-a-half-year contract, marking his entry into European football. He went on to become a key player at Olympique Lyonnais Football team, playing 71 matches in all competitions and scoring three goals.

5. He was Ready Made for the Premier League

Bruno joined Newcastle United on January 30, 2022, for a reported fee of £33 million, potentially rising to £40 million. At the time, he became the club's second-most expensive signing in The Magpies' history.

He made his debut in February 2022, contributing to a 3–1 win against Everton, and scored his first goal for the club in March, securing a 2–1 victory at Southampton. Over two and a half seasons, he played 109 matches and scored 17 goals for the Geordie club.

6. He Re-watches His Matches with His Parents Dick and Márcia Moura

Despite playing abroad, Bruno Guimarães maintains a close bond with his family. Whenever he returns to Brazil during holidays or festive periods, he takes the time to re-watch his matches with his parents, Dick and Márcia Moura. This tradition highlights the strong connection he shares with his father, mother, and place of birth, reflecting the deep roots and support system that have been pivotal throughout his career.

7. He was Eligible to Represent Spain Before Choosing Brazil Internationally

The defensive midfielder was initially eligible to play for Spain due to his heritage but ultimately chose to represent Brazil. He showcased his talent by first featuring for Brazil's under-23 team in the 2020 CONMEBOL Pre-Olympic Tournament and later earned a spot in the squad for the 2020 Summer Olympics.

In September 2020, Bruno received his call-up to the senior Brazil squad for World Cup qualifiers, making his debut in a memorable victory over Uruguay in November of the same year. His impressive performances led to his inclusion in the squad for the 2022 FIFA World Cup.

8. He is A Family Man

Bruno Guimarães, known for his dedication on and off the pitch, epitomises the role of a family man. In June 2023, he exchanged vows with his longtime partner, Ana Lidia Martins, in a heartfelt ceremony beneath the iconic Christ the Redeemer statue.

Their union has been blessed with two children: Matteo, born in October 2022, and Pietro, welcomed earlier this year in March 2024. Bruno's unwavering commitment to his family shines through in every aspect of his life, reflecting the values that anchor him beyond the football field.

9. His Unconventional Jersey Number 39 Has A Special Meaning

Bruno Guimarães’ father, Dick, worked tirelessly as a taxi driver to support the family and Bruno’s budding football career. This dedication profoundly influenced Bruno as he progressed through the youth ranks of Audax Rio.

When he signed for Lyon from Athletico Paranaense in 2020, the Brazil-born lad chose the number 39 jersey as a tribute to the number displayed on his father’s taxi, symbolising his gratitude for his father's hard work. He maintained this heartfelt tradition when he moved to Newcastle United, selecting the same number to honour his father's enduring influence and inspiration.
